title: Ukip immigration chief slammed for 'outrageous' retweet that echoed racist 1960s election slogan
text:
Ukip immigration chief slammed for 'outrageous' retweet that echoed racist 1960s election slogan John Bickley has now apologised after his retweet, which he has withdrawn, prompted fury among Labour MPs Share John Bickley with now-Ukip-leader Paul Nuttall back in 2015 (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Ukip's immigration spokesman was slammed today for retweeting an "outrageous" cartoon that echoed 1960s racism. 
John Bickley has now apologised after his retweet, which he has withdrawn, prompted fury among Labour MPs. 
Yet his leader Paul Nuttall has stood by him - saying he didn't realise its connotations. 
The cartoon featured Jeremy Corbyn driving a lorry full of people under the slogan "if you want a jihadi for a neighbour, vote Labour". 
This echoes notorious racist campaigning against Labour in the 1964 general election. Read More Tory councillor suspended over 'racist' retweet comparing Diane Abbott to an ape wearing lipstick 
That campaign saw right-wing activists in Smethwick, West Midlands, use the now-infamous slogan: "If you want a n****r neighbour, vote Labour". 
Mr Bickley, who is also a member of Ukip's ruling NEC and the party treasurer, said in a statement to the Huffington Post: "Yesterday I retweeted a cartoon about the potential consequences of Labourâ€™s support for uncontrolled immigration without realising it relied on a rhyme that had been used in an election in 1964 in racially abusive context. 
"I have since deleted the retweet and apologise for any offence caused." 
Despite the apology Labour MP John Spellar suggested Mr Bickley should be sacked. 
He branded the cartoon an "outrageous revival of a slogan from a disgraceful episode in Smethwick's history". 
Labour MEP Seb Dance added: "This shows true face of UKIP and why Labour should oppose them at every turn." 
Political commentator Peter Oborne said it was "horribly reminiscent of notorious racist Smethwick by-election in 1964." 
Pro-Corbyn campaign group Momentum branded the cartoon "disgusting and racist". 
But Ukip leader Paul Nuttall stood by Mr Bickley, saying at his campaign office where he is contesting next week's Stoke-on-Trent by-election: "He's got my support, absolutely, he's apologised for it." 
He added: "It wasn't clever and John's apologised and he's taken it down." Ukip leader Paul Nuttall stood by Mr Bickley while out campaigning today (Photo: Getty) 
Mr Nuttall claimed Mr Bickley had been "mortified". 
The party leader said: "He's not a politics anorak, John, and I don't think he understood the history of that slogan which goes back to the 1960s. 
"That was pointed out to him and as soon as it was, he was mortified by it and he took it down and he's apologised." 
The "n****r neighbour" slogan prompted a media storm ahead of the 1964 election. Harold Wilson at the time branded the slogan "absolutely squalid and degrading" (Photo: PA) 
Stickers branding the slogan were still found in Smethwick months after the Tories won the seat from Labour in the poll. 
At the time Labour's Harold Wilson, who won the election overall and became Prime Minister, branded the slogan "absolutely squalid and degrading". 
According to 1964 reports in The Times, he suggested the Tory candidate Peter Griffiths could be responsible. 
But Mr Griffiths responded by threatening to sue Mr Wilson for libel and said: "I have never used this phrase nor has any member of the Conservative Party in Smethwick. 
"It is not only a lie, it is a damned lie." Like us on Facebook
